content.question:
How does a pilot disconnect the autopilot in an aircraft equipped with a sidestick?
1- By pushing or pulling the sidestick hard
2- By pressing the A/P button on the glareshield
3- By pressing the takeover pushbutton
4- By moving the thrust levers

key_points: On an aircraft equipped with a sidestick, the autopilot (A/P) disengages when: - The flight crew presses the takeover pushbutton on the sidestick; (figure 1) - The flight crew presses the corresponding A/P pushbutton on the Flight Control Unit (FCU)/glareshield; (figure 2) - The flight crew pushes on the sidestick harder than a defined threshold, or moves on the rudder pedals beyond a defined threshold; - The flight crew moves the pitch trim wheel beyond a defined threshold; - The other A/P is engaged, except when localizer/glideslope modes are armed or engaged; - One of the engagement conditions is lost
learning.explanation: On an aircraft equipped with a sidestick, the autopilot (A/P) disengages when: - The flight crew presses the takeover pushbutton on the sidestick; (figure 1) - The flight crew presses the corresponding A/P pushbutton on the Flight Control Unit (FCU)/glareshield; (figure 2) - The flight crew pushes on the sidestick harder than a defined threshold, or moves on the rudder pedals beyond a defined threshold; - The flight crew moves the pitch trim wheel beyond a defined threshold; - The other A/P is engaged, except when localizer/glideslope modes are armed or engaged; - One of the engagement conditions is lost.

content.question: A Flight Director (FD) system basically consists of a computer that calculates…

options.A: flight path commands for use by the Flight Management System (FMS).
options.B: rate commands for use by the parallel actuators.
options.C: attitude commands for use by the Stability Augmentation System (SAS).
options.D: pitch and roll commands for use by the human or autopilot.

key_points: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude
Flight director information supplied by a FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI)
The vertical command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the bank angle of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. Flight director information supplied by a FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI). The vertical command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the bank angle of the aircraft. The vertical bar is always associated with the roll channel. The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft. The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel.

content.question: Assuming the autopilot is in heading hold mode, what would happen to the autopilot if the flux valve started drifting in an aircraft equipped with a single flux valve?

options.A: The autopilot would start drifting off too.
options.B: The autopilot would disengage automatically.
options.C: The 'FLUX ERROR' warning light would illuminate on the autopilot control panel, and the autopilot would use its internal logic to compensate for the error.
options.D: Nothing. The autopilot is independent from the flux valve.

key_points: A flux valve consists of two identical bars or spokes of highly permeable (easily magnetised and de-magnetised) material, mounted on a common hub

The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft (which also positions the compass card indicator – the indication of heading to the pilot)
Autopilot Heading Mode The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select, this is called Heading Mode
learning.explanation: A flux valve consists of two identical bars or spokes of highly permeable (easily magnetised and de-magnetised) material, mounted on a common hub. The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft (which also positions the compass card indicator – the indication of heading to the pilot). Autopilot Heading Mode The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select, this is called Heading Mode. In this mode the pilot selects a desired heading, either using a knob on the HSI, using the central FDS/autopilot panel or on the MCP. The Flight Director roll bar commands the aeroplane to fly to the Pre- Selected Heading, and subsequently to hold that heading. To achieve this, the computer receives inputs from the attitude reference source, the VG, and the course from the compass system. If the heading source is purely magnetic, the Autopilot will follow the heading regarding this source. If is is incorrect, the autopilot will follow an incorrect heading. Having two flux-valves with combined outputs, is used to reduce errors which otherwise may be present in systems using single pendulously mounted magnetic field responsive devices.

content.question: What commands does the flight director issue during take-off mode?

options.A: The pitch mode holds attitude to avoid obstacles and maintain adequate clearance, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the LOC.
options.B: The pitch mode holds a constant pitch attitude, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the LOC.
options.C: The pitch mode holds a constant pitch attitude to ensure obstacle clearance, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the SID.
options.D: The pitch mode commands an attitude to maintain a defined speed above V2 and tracks the runway heading.

key_points: The Flight Director takeoff mode is engaged by pressing either of the TO/GA switches on the throttles
The AFDS annunciation will be TO/GA
During take-off, prior to 60 KIAS, the initial FD commands are for 10° nose-down pitch and wings level
learning.explanation: The Flight Director takeoff mode is engaged by pressing either of the TO/GA switches on the throttles. The AFDS annunciation will be TO/GA. During take-off, prior to 60 KIAS, the initial FD commands are for 10° nose-down pitch and wings level. At 60 kt IAS, the FD command changes to 15° nose-up and wings level. At lift-off, the pitch command continues at 15° nose-up until sufficient climb rate is acquired. Pitch then commands MCP speed (normally V2) plus 20 knots. This speed is calculated and set during the pre-flight checks. The roll command maintains HDG SEL - the roll mode keeps the aircraft aligned with the runway heading. Next, when either autopilot is engaged or when the MCP speed selector is rotated, 20 kt IAS is added automatically to the MCP IAS display.

content.question:
The flight guidance system has different modes. Considering the autopilot/flight director, which of the following describes one feature of the go-around mode?
When selected, the go-around mode engages and the aeroplane climbs...

options.A: only if the aeroplane is below the selected missed approach altitude and following an ILS.
options.B: when it is approaching the missed approach point or minimum descent altitude for the approach.
options.C: whether it is below or above the selected missed approach altitude at the point of initiation.
options.D: only if the selected missed approach altitude is above the aeroplane at the point of initiation.

learning.explanation: 022.06.02.01.08: Explain the following mixed modes: take-off and go-around (TOGA); approach (APP). The Go-around mode is one of the three mixed modes mentioned in the EASA LOs above, with the other two being take-off and approach modes. All three of these modes interact with the autothrottle and autopilot systems to achieve the desired outcomes. When the A/T ARM switch is turned on, the A/T go-around mode becomes active below 2000 feet RA, whether or not the AFDS is engaged. Once activated, the A/T go-around mode remains available for engagement until 2 seconds after touchdown. To engage this mode, you simply press the TOGA switch. When engaged, "GA" is displayed for the A/T, and the thrust levers move to the reduced go-around thrust setting, resulting in a climb rate of 1000 to 2000 feet per minute. Pressing the TOGA switch a second time causes the A/T to advance the thrust to the full go-around N1 limit. On Boeing aircraft, this entails pressing TOGA, while on Airbus planes, it involves moving the throttles into the TOGA detent. In either case, the engines power up to full thrust, and the autopilot disengages the approach mode, allowing the aircraft to climb away from the ground. It's important to note that the Go-around mode is not constrained by specific altitudes or heights. Therefore, if the pilot initiates a go-around, the aircraft will climb regardless of whether it is below or above the pre-selected missed approach altitude.

content.question: During an automatic landing, between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot maintains…

options.A: a vertical speed depending on the GPS height.
options.B: a constant flight path angle with reference to the ground.
options.C: a constant vertical speed.
options.D: a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height.

key_points: For an A320 or B737, a standard VS at a standard glide path angle and aircraft weight is between 700 and 800 ft/min
As you can imagine if the aircraft keeps this rate of descent until touch down, it will do nothing but making a hole into the runway
Therefore, the autopilot system needs some inputs to flare the aircraft and achieve a smooth touch down
learning.explanation: For an A320 or B737, a standard VS at a standard glide path angle and aircraft weight is between 700 and 800 ft/min. As you can imagine if the aircraft keeps this rate of descent until touch down, it will do nothing but making a hole into the runway. Therefore, the autopilot system needs some inputs to flare the aircraft and achieve a smooth touch down. These inputs are the radio height, the wind speed/direction, etc. At 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
During an autoland, what triggers the FLARE mode?

options.A: The glide slope mode.
options.B: The radio altitude, when it reaches about 50 ft.
options.C: The barometric altitude, when it reaches about 50 ft.
options.D: The localizer mode.

key_points: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III
An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions

Fail-passive automatic landing system An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III. An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions. Fail-passive automatic landing system An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail passive means in case of a failure of any part of the system the autoland system will turn itself off and the crew has to take over. An example of an autoland sequence: - Approach (APP) mode armed - Localizer and Glide Slope Armed - Localizer Capture - Glide Slope Capture - 400 - 330 feet RA: If FLARE is armed by approximately 350 ft RA, both A/Ps automatically disengage. - At 45 feet Gear Altitude (GA)/50 ft RA: The FLARE mode is automatically engaged - Roll-out In case visual references at the moment of an abnormal occurrence (such as 'NO FLARE' indication) are sufficient and flying conditions such that a visual manual landing can be safely performed, continuation of the approach remains always an option and a crew decision.

content.question: Which of the following is correct regarding the initial phase of the autopilot?

options.A: A given rate of change of trajectory is maintained to achieve a new parameter without undershooting.
options.B: A new trajectory is obtained via a change in attitude to achieve a desired parameter.
options.C: The autopilot obtains a trajectory through the third channel in case of failure.
options.D: The autopilot maintains the set parameter without any change.

key_points: When a mode is engaged, the following sequence of events applies: Initial phase In this phase, the attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter
The trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter
Capture phase The aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting
learning.explanation: When a mode is engaged, the following sequence of events applies: Initial phase In this phase, the attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter. The trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter. Capture phase The aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting. Tracking or hold phase The aircraft will maintain the set parameter until a new change has been initiated.

content.question: Which statement is correct regarding the V/S and FPA autopilot modes?

options.A: V/S is an altitude gain/loss in relation to time while FPA is an altitude gain/loss in relation to ground distance.
options.B: Both V/S and FPA maintain a vertical speed as it is the main parameter during climb and descent.
options.C: V/S is an altitude gain/loss in relation to ground distance while FPA is an altitude gain/loss in relation to time.
options.D: FPA is to be used during non-precision approaches only, whereas V/S can be used during any other approach.

key_points: The V/S - FPA mode is a selected mode
It acquires and holds the vertical speed or the flight path angle displayed in the V/S - FPA window of the FCU
VERTICAL SPEED An aircraft's vertical speed is the positive or negative rate of altitude change with respect to time
learning.explanation: The V/S - FPA mode is a selected mode. It acquires and holds the vertical speed or the flight path angle displayed in the V/S - FPA window of the FCU. VERTICAL SPEED An aircraft's vertical speed is the positive or negative rate of altitude change with respect to time. This is usually expressed in feet per minute (ft/min). The Vertical Speed in an aircraft is indicated with a vertical speed indicator (VSI) or instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI). FLIGHT PATH ANGLE The Flight Path Angle is the angle between the Aircraft’s Velocity Vector and the Horizon. If you are flying in a level flight your Flight Path Angle will be zero (over the horizon), regardless of the Pitch Angle. During a descent, the Flight Path Angle will be negative (below the horizon) thus when climbing the Flight Path Angle will be positive (over the horizon). FLIGHT PATH VECTOR The circular symbol represents the aircraft's axis in relation to the vertical and lateral movement referenced to the Earth's surface. If you were stationary on the ground, the circle would be on the horizon line and centred in the display. The data received by the FPV is derived mostly from the Internal Reference System (IRS) of the aircraft; therefore, the Flight Path Vector provides an almost instantaneous display of flight path angle and drift information.

content.question: The basic modes of an autopilot consist of…

options.A: controlling the path of the aircraft vertically only.
options.B: controlling the path of the aircraft horizontally or vertically.
options.C: stabilising the aircraft around its centre of gravity.
options.D: controlling the movement of the centre of gravity of the aircraft.

key_points: Basic modes – Stabilizing the aircraft around its center of gravity
The basic stability functions of the autopilot are provided by the inner loops
Guidance functions – Controlling the movements of the center of gravity in three-dimensional space
learning.explanation: Basic modes – Stabilizing the aircraft around its center of gravity. The basic stability functions of the autopilot are provided by the inner loops. Guidance functions – Controlling the movements of the center of gravity in three-dimensional space. These are the different functions of the autopilot that control the path of the aircraft. The guidance functions are provided by the outer loops. Guidance functions: ROLL modes PITCH modes Combined ROLL and PITCH Heading Select and Hold Altitude Select and Hold Approach Track Hold IAS/Mach Hold Go-around VOR/LOC Capture and Track Level Change Lateral Navigation LNAV Altitude Capture Vertical Speed Glideslope Capture and Track Basic (stabilization) functions: Pitch and bank angle hold (= attitude hold) Vertical Speed hold Wings level hold

content.question:
During a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the G/S mode (tracking of ILS Glide Slope). The position of the horizontal command bar indicates:
1 – the position of the aircraft relative to the ILS Glide Slope
2 – the correction to be applied to the pitch angle in order to capture and follow the ILS Glide Slope
3 – the pitch angle of the aircraft
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft
The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel
When tracking the ILS glideslope, the horizontal command bar will indicate at which angle you should pitch the aircraft in order to get back on the glideslope
learning.explanation: The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft. The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel. When tracking the ILS glideslope, the horizontal command bar will indicate at which angle you should pitch the aircraft in order to get back on the glideslope. In other words, it will indicate the correction to be applied to the pitch angle in order to capture and then readapt this pitch angle so that you follow the ILS glideslope.

content.question: The pilot sets the autobrake to MAX due to fear of exceeding runway distance. The pilot will…

options.A: Not use reverse thrust.
options.B: Expect the autobrake system to apply necessary braking to stay on the runway.
options.C: Expect the autobrake system to apply maximum braking effort.
options.D: Expect the autobrake system to modulate braking pressure to maintain given rate.

key_points: Learning Objectives 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 021.04.03.04.04: Describe how an autobrake system setting will either apply maximum braking (RTO or MAX) or result in a given rate of deceleration, where the amount of braking applied may be affected by: the use of reverse thrust; slippery runway. While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above. Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. Note: On a Boeing 737, the 1, 2, 3, and MAX deceleration positions control the autobrake system during landing, modulating brake pressure to achieve specified deceleration rates until the aircraft comes to a complete stop. Regarding other options, the use of reverse thrust and autobrake is not mutually exclusive - Flight crews can employ reverse thrust in conjunction with autobrake for maximum deceleration. Although the autobrake system is designed to facilitate a smooth landing rollout and keep the aircraft on the runway, pilots must always conduct calculations to ensure that the aircraft does not exceed the available landing distance.

content.question:
On a large aeroplane, the computer of the autopilot system uses, among others, input signals from the:
1 – ADC
2 – Attitude reference system
3 – ILS receiver
4 – Autopilot mode control panel
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: In an autopilot system, the inner loops provide the stability functions, and the outer loops provide the guidance functions

The main components of an AP are the: Actuators, Autopilot MCP (mode control panel), FMA (flight mode annunciator (Airbus), mode annunciator panel (Boeing)), Computer, which uses inputs from the ADC (CAS, altitude), the MCP, and the attitude reference system (heading, attitude, vertical speed), the ILS receiver, etc
learning.explanation: In an autopilot system, the inner loops provide the stability functions, and the outer loops provide the guidance functions. The main components of an AP are the: Actuators, Autopilot MCP (mode control panel), FMA (flight mode annunciator (Airbus), mode annunciator panel (Boeing)), Computer, which uses inputs from the ADC (CAS, altitude), the MCP, and the attitude reference system (heading, attitude, vertical speed), the ILS receiver, etc.

content.question: In an autopilot system, What does the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) indicate?

options.A: Flight Warning System (FWS) modes.
options.B: AFCS and autothrust modes.
options.C: Weather radar modes.
options.D: EGPWS modes.

key_points: The Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is usually located on the top of the PFD and displays the active and the armed modes of the autopilot and auto-thrust (or auto-throttle) system
The flight crew uses this system to check and confirm any selection made on the autopilot control panel
From left to right, the FMA indicates the: Auto-thrust mode and autobrake modes (on more complex aircraft such as the A350)
learning.explanation: The Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is usually located on the top of the PFD and displays the active and the armed modes of the autopilot and auto-thrust (or auto-throttle) system. The flight crew uses this system to check and confirm any selection made on the autopilot control panel. From left to right, the FMA indicates the: Auto-thrust mode and autobrake modes (on more complex aircraft such as the A350). Autopilot/FD vertical modes. Autopilot/FD lateral modes. Approach capabilities (=autoland capabilities) and autopilot designator (1, 2, 1+2) and auto-thrust engagement status.

content.question: What happens if, during an automatic approach and landing, the radio altimeter fails?

options.A: The automatic landing system will NOT be able to perform the flare phase.
options.B: The automatic landing system will be fully operational.
options.C: The automatic braking sequence will be impacted.
options.D: The Glide Slope mode will NOT be operational.

key_points: When performing an automatic landing, a radio altimeter is required because the decision heights below CAT I limits (200 ft) are based on radio height and because the autopilot moves from one mode to another, for example, from FLARE to ROLLOUT, using a variety of inputs, particularly radio height
Should the radio altimeter fail during the autoland procedure, the height indication is removed and replaced by a warning flag
As the individual steps of the automatic landing procedure are triggered by radio heights, this situation requires the aircraft to go around and be landed manually
learning.explanation: When performing an automatic landing, a radio altimeter is required because the decision heights below CAT I limits (200 ft) are based on radio height and because the autopilot moves from one mode to another, for example, from FLARE to ROLLOUT, using a variety of inputs, particularly radio height. Should the radio altimeter fail during the autoland procedure, the height indication is removed and replaced by a warning flag. As the individual steps of the automatic landing procedure are triggered by radio heights, this situation requires the aircraft to go around and be landed manually. As for the incorrect options: Glideslope relies upon the ILS and not the radio altimeter. The autobrake relies on weight-on-wheels, throttles retarded and wheels spun up to speed. The autoland will not be fully operational.

content.question: An autoland system (autopilot) is described as fail operational when it is…

options.A: Fail operational hybrid system.
options.B: Fail redundant.
options.C: Fail passive.
options.D: Fail safe.

key_points: EASA AIR OPS CS-AWO 300 Applicability and Terminology Fail-passive Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically

Fail-operational Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system

A fail-safe is a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause minimal or no harm to other equipment, to the environment or to people
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS CS-AWO 300 Applicability and Terminology Fail-passive Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail-operational Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system. A fail-safe is a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause minimal or no harm to other equipment, to the environment or to people. Therefore, we can say that fail-operational is fail-safe.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the system which ensures synchronisation in an autopilot slaved powered control circuit?

options.A: Such system can itself, when it fails, prevent the automatic pilot from being engaged.
options.B: Synchronisation is inhibited when the automatic pilot is engaged.
options.C: This system prevents uncommanded surface deflection when the automatic pilot is disengaged.
options.D: It intervenes only when the automatic pilot has been engaged.

key_points: AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION Before the autopilot is engaged, it must be ensured that the take-over is effected smoothly and without "snatching" of the aircraft's control system
This is achieved by synchronization of aircraft control systems
Autopilot systems synchronization is effected by designed synchronizing circuits
learning.explanation: AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION Before the autopilot is engaged, it must be ensured that the take-over is effected smoothly and without "snatching" of the aircraft's control system. This is achieved by synchronization of aircraft control systems. Autopilot systems synchronization is effected by designed synchronizing circuits. These synchronizing circuits will automatically sense any existing "standing signals" in the pitch and roll channels and automatically send this data to a synchronizer unit. The synchronizer unit will create equal and opposite attitude signal. Without the synchronizing circuits, the autopilot engagement could cause unwanted and/or violent aircraft manoeuvres. Therefore, it is important to note that, in the event of a synchronizing circuits failure, the autopilot may be prevented from engaging.

content.question: The purpose of a flight director is to…

options.A: convey air traffic control information to the pilot.
options.B: provide an automatic landing system function.
options.C: automatically steer the aircraft to waypoints selected on the CDU.
options.D: reduce the pilots workload by presenting data in the form of control commands.

key_points: ‘convey air traffic control information to the pilot’ – the FD system is not linked in any way with the information provided by the ATC
‘provide an automatic landing system function’ – the FD is most of the time ON during Autoland, however, it is not the main system allowing the automatic landing
The systems crucial to the Autoland are the autopilot, the radio, altimeter, and the auto-throttle system
learning.explanation: ‘convey air traffic control information to the pilot’ – the FD system is not linked in any way with the information provided by the ATC. ‘provide an automatic landing system function’ – the FD is most of the time ON during Autoland, however, it is not the main system allowing the automatic landing. The systems crucial to the Autoland are the autopilot, the radio, altimeter, and the auto-throttle system. ‘automatically steer the aircraft to waypoints selected on the CDU’ – it is the autopilot’s function to automatically follow the flight plan inserted in the FMS via the CDU. The autopilot can operate without the FDs ON, so this answer option is also incorrect. ‘reduce the pilots' workload by presenting data in the form of control commands’ – the flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. When flying manually, the FD bars indicate the optimum path according to the selected modes, and this ultimately reduces their workload.

content.question: The crew is flying a heading assigned by ATC, 20 NM to the left and parallel to the planned route, for weather avoidance. Just after you pass the weather, ATC clears you to continue on your flight planned route. You select the lateral navigation mode and the Pilot Monitoring (PM) reads the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA), the navigation mode is armed. What will the aircraft do when it arrives abeam the right turn at the next waypoint on the Flight Management Computer (FMC) flight plan?

options.A: It will continue on the current heading, unless a heading intercepting the flight plan has been set by the pilot.
options.B: It will continue to parallel the planned route by offset by 20 NM to the left, so the aircraft will execute a right turn.
options.C: It will turn right towards the next waypoint.
options.D: It will enter an ICAO standard holding pattern.

key_points: With the Navigation Mode ARMED, it will automatically engage if the aircraft heading/track line intercepts the active flight plan before the TO waypoint and the aircraft reaches the active flight plan leg

In this case, the pilot would have to ask for a heading to the right to intercept the active flight plane or insert a DIRECT TO the next waypoint, otherwise the aircraft would maintain present heading
learning.explanation: With the Navigation Mode ARMED, it will automatically engage if the aircraft heading/track line intercepts the active flight plan before the TO waypoint and the aircraft reaches the active flight plan leg. In this case, the pilot would have to ask for a heading to the right to intercept the active flight plane or insert a DIRECT TO the next waypoint, otherwise the aircraft would maintain present heading.

content.question: During cruise with full automation engaged and the autothrottle in speed mode. How is speed control achieved?

options.A: The autothrottle will vary engine thrust, while the autopilot varies the aircraft pitch to maintain altitude.
options.B: The autothrottle maintains constant engine thrust, while the autopilot uses the elevator to maintain altitude.
options.C: The autopilot varies the aircraft pitch, while the autothrottle maintains constant engine thrust.
options.D: The autopilot maintains constant pitch, while the autothrottle maintains rated N1 thrust.

learning.explanation: 022.09.01.01.07: Explain the principles of speed control and how speed can be controlled: by varying the engine thrust; by varying the aircraft pitch. SPEED MODE The autothrottle speed mode is activated in cruise and during climb or descent with a prescribed rate. In speed mode, the autothrottle will maintain a preselected airspeed (CAS) or Mach number. The autothrottle will compute and command the new required thrust or power setting to comply with the airspeed selection. At the same time, the autopilot pitch channel will maintain the selected altitude or vertical rate by adjusting the aircraft’s pitch.

content.question: During an auto coupled approach, where can the pilots verify the landing capability of the aircraft?

options.A: FMA that is located on the MCP or FCU.
options.B: Thrust mode display that is located on the MCP or FCU.
options.C: Thrust mode display that is located on each pilot's PFD.
options.D: FMA that is located on each pilot's PFD.

key_points: EFIS equipped aircraft display the appropriate information on the PFD/EADI in an area called the Flight Mode Annunciator
As the same space can be used for all the different messages, it can be kept small
Here all the modes for the FD autothrottle and autopilot are displayed
learning.explanation: EFIS equipped aircraft display the appropriate information on the PFD/EADI in an area called the Flight Mode Annunciator. As the same space can be used for all the different messages, it can be kept small. Here all the modes for the FD autothrottle and autopilot are displayed. Newly changed information is often emphasized on the FMA type display by surrounding it in a box. Engaged modes are shown on the top line in green while armed modes are on the line below in white. More capable systems will have more functions and consequently more lights, such as those indicating the state of the autothrottle, landing capability and flare or go-around modes.

key_points: The Flight Guidance (FG) part of the FMGS controls: ‐ The Flight Director (FD) ‐ The Autopilot (AP) ‐ The Autothrust (A/THR)
The AP and FD pitch modes can control a target SPD/MACH or a vertical trajectory, and the A/THR mode can control a fixed thrust or a target SPD/MACH
However, the AP/FD and the A/THR cannot both control a target SPD/MACH simultaneously
learning.explanation: The Flight Guidance (FG) part of the FMGS controls: ‐ The Flight Director (FD) ‐ The Autopilot (AP) ‐ The Autothrust (A/THR). The AP and FD pitch modes can control a target SPD/MACH or a vertical trajectory, and the A/THR mode can control a fixed thrust or a target SPD/MACH. However, the AP/FD and the A/THR cannot both control a target SPD/MACH simultaneously. Therefore the AP/FD pitch modes and A/THR mode are coordinated as follows: ‐ If an AP/FD pitch mode controls a vertical trajectory, the A/THR mode controls the target SPD/MACH. ‐ If an AP/FD pitch mode controls a target SPD or MACH, the A/THR mode controls the thrust. ‐ If no AP/FD pitch mode is engaged, the A/THR mode reverts to controlling the SPD/MACH mode. In other words, the selection of an AP/FD pitch mode determines which mode the A/THR controls. The FMGS has guidance parameters for both AP/FD lateral and vertical modes. The AP/FD lateral modes are the same. Two types of autopilot and flight director modes are available to guide the aircraft: ‐ One that steers the aircraft along the lateral, vertical, and speed profiles according to the data the pilot inserts into the MCDU. Flight Management (in the Flight Management and Guidance Computer) computes the corresponding guidance targets. ‐ The other that steers the aircraft according to target values that the pilot selects and the FCU windows display.

key_points: The ICAO envelope for glide slope signal quality ICAO guidelines provide recommendations for ensuring the quality of the ILS glide slope signal
Periodic checks on all ILS equipped runways ensure that the ILS signal quality is at the required level inside a defined envelope
Capturing the ILS glide slope within this envelope ensures that the aircraft is within the area of influence for the primary glide slope
learning.explanation: The ICAO envelope for glide slope signal quality ICAO guidelines provide recommendations for ensuring the quality of the ILS glide slope signal. Periodic checks on all ILS equipped runways ensure that the ILS signal quality is at the required level inside a defined envelope. Capturing the ILS glide slope within this envelope ensures that the aircraft is within the area of influence for the primary glide slope. It also ensures that the ILS signal is of sufficient quality to ensure a normal ILS glide slope capture. The ICAO envelope (fig.4) is within: 10 NM from the runway threshold +/-8° laterally from the runway centerline 0.3 x Θ up to 1.75 x Θ (Θ, being the nominal glide path angle). Make sure the aircraft is in the correct ILS envelope. Arming the approach too soon may cause a false Glide Slope interception out of the protected area, making the airplane descend outside the normal glide slope capture zone. Further information: Secondary glide slopes are an inevitable characteristic due to the ILS antenna design. When an aircraft flies well above the main glide slope, the glide slope deviations displayed on the PFD will refer to the nearest glide slope, which may be a secondary glide slope instead of the primary one. This can lead both the flight crew and the autopilot to erroneously consider the secondary glide slope as the reference for the final descent.

Consider a fail-passive autoland system similar to those found on modern transport aircrafts. In the event of a failure of an autopilot:

key_points: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational

Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands
In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational. Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands. In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - The automatic landing system consists of three independent autopilot channels per controlled axis, it is capable of determining the failed component and excluding it from the computation. In the event of a failure, the approach, flare, and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system.

key_points: Vertical Navigation (VNAV) VNAV provides vertical profile guidance through the climb, cruise, and descent phases of flight
VNAV controls the path and speed to comply with waypoint crossing restrictions
Waypoint crossing restrictions are entered on the LEGS page waypoint line by pushing the applicable key on the right side of the CDU
learning.explanation: Vertical Navigation (VNAV) VNAV provides vertical profile guidance through the climb, cruise, and descent phases of flight. VNAV controls the path and speed to comply with waypoint crossing restrictions. Waypoint crossing restrictions are entered on the LEGS page waypoint line by pushing the applicable key on the right side of the CDU. Barometric altitude restrictions must be below the cruise altitude to be valid. The speed descent normally begins automatically at the calculated Top of Descent, provided the MCP altitude is reset for the descent. At the T/D, the FMC commands pitch to maintain target descent speed.

key_points: Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight, with the human crew supervising the process
Between 50 ft and 40 ft RA, FLARE mode will engage and is completed at touchdown
The FLARE annunciation indicates the second autopilot is fully engaged
learning.explanation: Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight, with the human crew supervising the process. Between 50 ft and 40 ft RA, FLARE mode will engage and is completed at touchdown. The FLARE annunciation indicates the second autopilot is fully engaged. As the lowest weather minimums are directly related to the system status, both pilots must observe the FLARE annunciation. Furthermore, without the flare mode, the aircraft will not be able to land by itself - it will keep the same descent rate down to the threshold. In case the flare mode does not engage, the pilot shall perform a go-around.

key_points: It is possible to arm a mode, which means that it will automatically be engaged once certain criteria are met
For example, during climb with VS active, another vertical mode such as ALT can be armed
Once the aircraft approaches the newly selected level, VS will be disengaged and replaced by the previous armed ALT mode
learning.explanation: It is possible to arm a mode, which means that it will automatically be engaged once certain criteria are met. For example, during climb with VS active, another vertical mode such as ALT can be armed. Once the aircraft approaches the newly selected level, VS will be disengaged and replaced by the previous armed ALT mode. "ALT engaged" incorrect ⇒ if you engage ALT, the aircraft will capture the current altitude. The correct sequence would be to engage VS at the desired rate of climb (800 ft/min), arm the altitude 6000 ft so that it captures the desired altitude. VS will then disengage and will be replaced by ALT.

content.question: Which of the following aircraft components are incorporated in an Autoland system?

options.A: Flight controls, hydraulics, and control columns.
options.B: Autopilot(s), autothrust, and control columns.
options.C: Flight controls, hydraulics, and radio altimeter(s).
options.D: Autopilot(s), autothrust, and radio altimeter(s).

key_points: The radio altimeter can be defined as a self-contained on-board aid used to measure the true height of the aircraft
The RA operates between 4200 MHz and 4400 MHz and the maximum range for the indication is typically from the ground up to 2500 ft
Therefore, besides the autopilot (for obvious reasons) it is the primary source of information during an automatic landing
learning.explanation: The radio altimeter can be defined as a self-contained on-board aid used to measure the true height of the aircraft. The RA operates between 4200 MHz and 4400 MHz and the maximum range for the indication is typically from the ground up to 2500 ft. Therefore, besides the autopilot (for obvious reasons) it is the primary source of information during an automatic landing. The transition from one phase to another during the autoland is based on the height measured by the radio altimeter. For example, at 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare. The auto-thrust is also incorporated in the Autoland system as this provides automatic speed control until touchdown. The pilot will retard the thrust levers at about 10-20 ft (RA) before touchdown.

content.question: Are there any flight envelope protections available in mechanical backup mode?

options.A: Flight envelope protection is provided in mechanical backup mode but with reduced capabilities.
options.B: Yes, flight envelope protection is always provided regardless of the mode.
options.C: No, flight envelope protection is not provided in mechanical backup mode.
options.D: Flight envelope protection is only partially provided in mechanical backup mode.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire aircraft such as the A320 have their Flight Control System divided into Flight Control Laws: Normal Law and reconfiguration laws - Alternate Law, Direct Law and Mechanical Backup
In normal law, the system offers flight envelope protections: - load factor limitation - pitch attitude protection - high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection - high-speed protection
Depending on the failure, it can lead to a reconfiguration law with reduced or no protections at all
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire aircraft such as the A320 have their Flight Control System divided into Flight Control Laws: Normal Law and reconfiguration laws - Alternate Law, Direct Law and Mechanical Backup. In normal law, the system offers flight envelope protections: - load factor limitation - pitch attitude protection - high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection - high-speed protection. Depending on the failure, it can lead to a reconfiguration law with reduced or no protections at all. In the case of Mechanical Back-up, no flight envelope protections are provided. MECHANICAL BACK-UP The purpose of the mechanical backup is to achieve all safety objectives in MMEL dispatch condition: to manage a temporary and total electrical loss, the temporary loss of five fly-by-wire computers, the loss of both elevators, or the total loss of ailerons and spoilers. Pitch - The pilot manually applies trim to the THS to control the aircraft in pitch. Lateral - The pilot uses the rudder pedals as the mechanical backup to laterally control the aircraft.

content.question: The pilot of a modern, large turbojet aeroplane sets the vertical speed mode of the autopilot to carry out a climb. What must he/she be particularly careful of?

options.A: The autopilot may select a rate of climb outside the maximum permissible limit of the aeroplane.
options.B: The engines may overspeed as the autothrottle attempts to maintain airspeed.
options.C: The aeroplane may overspeed in an attempt to maintain the rate of climb.
options.D: If the climb is prolonged, there is a risk that the airspeed may reduce towards the stall.

key_points: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode
In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S
The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH
learning.explanation: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode. In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S. The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH. The V/S guidance has priority over the speed guidance. If the selected target V/S is too high (relative to the current thrust condition and speed), the FMGC will steer the aircraft to the target V/S, but the aircraft will also accelerate or decelerate. As altitude increases and the air gets thinner, the IAS will reduce for a given pitch setting. Consequently, the angle of attack also reduces. As a result, the vertical speed will reduce for a certain pitch attitude. The autopilot will therefore chase the selected vertical speed by pitching up. This results in further decreased IAS. Ultimately, this could lead to a stall.

content.question: The pilot engages the autopilot and selects Vertical Speed (VS) mode during the climb. If an excessive Vertical Speed is selected, the risk would be…

options.A: An exceedance of the Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT) limit.
options.B: An uncontrolled loss of airspeed.
options.C: A wrong airspeed indication.
options.D: A level bust.

key_points: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents
In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed

When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected
learning.explanation: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents. In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed. When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected. As the power of aircraft is limited at a certain altitude it may not be able to achieve targeted vertical speed. If you command it to climb at a greater FPM rate than your aircraft can perform at that altitude airspeed decays, the autopilot will continually pitch the aircraft up in an attempt to maintain the vertical speed selected. This could happen all the way to the point of stalling.

content.question: When an aircraft, operating in the VOR coupled mode, enters the "cone of confusion" over a VOR station, the roll channel of the autopilot…

options.A: is temporarily disconnected.
options.B: temporarily maintains existing heading.
options.C: remains always coupled to the selected VOR radial.
options.D: is damped by a trim input signal from the lateral trim system.

key_points: Over the ‘cone of confusion’ of a VOR station, the onboard receiver is not able to detect anymore the radial your autopilot was tracking in the VOR mode
As the VOR needle will spin around the autopilot cannot follow and command such instructions
Therefore, the roll channel was designed so that it temporarily maintains the lastly memorized heading before the aircraft entered the ‘con of confusion’
learning.explanation: Over the ‘cone of confusion’ of a VOR station, the onboard receiver is not able to detect anymore the radial your autopilot was tracking in the VOR mode. As the VOR needle will spin around the autopilot cannot follow and command such instructions. Therefore, the roll channel was designed so that it temporarily maintains the lastly memorized heading before the aircraft entered the ‘con of confusion’. After leaving the ‘cone of confusion’, the autopilot will revert back to VOR mode.

content.question: When talking about an engaged autopilot mode, the initial phase is where the...

options.A: attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory.
options.B: pilot is programming the autopilot on the ground before take-off.
options.C: aircraft maintains a set parameter.
options.D: aircraft is waiting for a certain set of parameters to engage the mode in question.

key_points: The autopilot is capable of producing the same actions as the pilot to maintain aircraft stability in a shorter reaction time
The autopilot is able to: - Sense changes in attitude
- Compute the amount and direction of control required
learning.explanation: The autopilot is capable of producing the same actions as the pilot to maintain aircraft stability in a shorter reaction time. The autopilot is able to: - Sense changes in attitude. - Compute the amount and direction of control required. - Provide the muscle to move the control surfaces using servomotors. - Detect that the control has been applied and that the aircraft has responded. - Return control surfaces back to the neutral condition when the disturbance has been corrected. Before coupling an autopilot with the aircraft’s control system the integrity of the Autopilot Inner Loop must be established to ensure that it may safely take control of the aircraft. AUTOPILOT CONDITIONS OF ENGAGEMENT Before the autopilot can be engaged, certain conditions must be met. These conditions vary with aircraft type. The sequence of events when a mode is engaged and the different phases are as follows: - initial phase: where attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter; the trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter; - capture phase: where the aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting; - tracking or hold phase: where the aircraft will maintain the set parameter until a new change has been initiated.

options.D: The FD and the autopilot share the same control panel, but the available modes are different. The FD bars shown on the PFD are unreliable when both FD and autopilot are engaged.

The primary distinction between the Flight Director System (FDS) and the autopilot lies in their operational roles. The FDS exclusively offers control and guidance instructions to either the pilot or the autopilot, whereas the autopilot physically controls the aircraft's surfaces. The FDS, however, serves as a precise means of cross-verifying the control and guidance commands sent to the autopilot. The FDS can be employed in the following ways: • Flight director mode only: In this scenario, the pilot manually operates the flight controls, adhering to the FDS commands. This typically occurs during the final stages of an approach, particularly for non-automated landings. • Autopilot mode only: Here, the pilot provides sensory guidance to the autopilot via the aircraft's control column/stick. This often happens when pilots are using the autopilot in control wheel steering (CWS) mode. • Flight director and autopilot mode: In this mode, the autopilot adjusts the aircraft's control surfaces in response to the steering commands issued by the FDS. This is common during cruising and most other phases of a commercial transport flight. The modes and control panel are the same for both the Flight Director (FD) and the autopilot. The FD will present on the Primary Flight Display (PFD) the instructions that the autopilot is following to meet the preset parameters.

key_points: The Fail-Operational Automatic Landing System A fail-operational automatic landing system is defined as the capability of a system to withstand a failure without affecting the overall functioning of the system and without causing degradation of performance beyond the limits required for an automatic landing
The system requires a minimum of three autopilots
Alert Height The alert height is a specified radio altimeter height, based on the characteristics of the aircraft and its fail operational landing system
learning.explanation: The Fail-Operational Automatic Landing System A fail-operational automatic landing system is defined as the capability of a system to withstand a failure without affecting the overall functioning of the system and without causing degradation of performance beyond the limits required for an automatic landing. The system requires a minimum of three autopilots. Alert Height The alert height is a specified radio altimeter height, based on the characteristics of the aircraft and its fail operational landing system. In operational use, if a failure occurred above the alert height in one of the required redundant operational systems in the aircraft, the approach would be discontinued, and a go-around executed unless reversion to a higher decision height is possible. If a failure in one of the required redundant operational systems occurred below the alert height, it would be ignored, and the approach would be continued to complete the autoland. If below the alert height all autopilots disengage, the ILS signal is lost, excessive ILS deviations occur, or the radio-altimeter fails, a warning will be triggered and an autoland procedure will not be possible.

learning.explanation: AUTOLAND Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight. The pilots assume a monitoring role during the final stages of the approach and will only intervene in the event of a system failure or emergency and, after landing, to taxi the aircraft off of the runway and to the parking location. Pilot-induced oscillations are where the pilot "over-controls" the aircraft, and therefore, will not only correct for an incorrect attitude, altitude, speed, etc., but will over-correct, and go through the equilibrium, ending up in the opposite scenario. This can often be seen on a pilot's first few ILS approaches when they begin to get very accurate near the runway, or during the flare, when pilots sometimes over-flare, and end up porpoising (up and down) along the runway. It is very common in many stages of flight, and something to try and avoid. Autopilots can perform self-induced oscillations too, if they are not quick enough to catch the overcontrolling with their feedback loop, for example. This could be in pitch, or in yaw and roll (which could lead to Dutch roll). This question is very vague, it does not tell us what oscillations we are feeling, nor much about how they have been formed, so we have chosen the most vague answer that is correct (it could also be Dutch roll, but we would have to make a lot more assumptions, so we think that "Dutch roll" is not as correct).

learning.explanation: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III. An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions. learning.explanation: When a pilot disconnects the autopilot to fly manually, the Flight Director (FD) can still be used for guidance. Upon autopilot disengagement, the FD will typically move to display the desired pitch and bank commands that the pilot should follow in order to maintain the planned trajectory. The FD provides a visual cue to the pilot, indicating the required control inputs needed to maintain the desired flight path, which the pilot then follows. key_points: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of Fly-By-Wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

learning.explanation: Fail passive - In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - In the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system. Note: A fail-operational system experiencing a failure will become a fail passive. A fail passive system can still complete the landing automatically but it has no redundancy anymore. So, if it fails once again, it will not be able to complete the landing automatically.

content.question: Approaching top of descent, the destination aerodrome ATIS includes RVRs around 200 m, with Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) in force. The Commander's windscreen heat failed, with an annunciated alert, in the cruise. The screen is clear. What implications does the failure have on the briefing for the approach and landing?

options.A: Because the failure was annunciated, if there is any consequent autoland capability downgrade, this will also be annunciated. In case autoland capability remains unchanged, a CAT III approach may be flown.
options.B: A check of the manuals is required, in case the defect causes a reduction in the aircraft's approach capability. Diversion, or a higher height and/or RVR might be necessary.
options.C: All aircraft systems are required to be serviceable for low visibility procedures, so diversion to a CAT I aerodrome will be necessary.
options.D: The autoland capability should NOT be affected by the windscreen heating failure, therefore NO action is necessary.

key_points: The answer provides a good and complete answer to this question: Obviously, failure or malfunctions of any of the systems required to perform an automatic landing can result in a degradation of autoland performance
Additionally, systems which are not directly involved in the autoland sequency can also affect the ability to perform automatic landing and probably result in higher minima
Thus, the pilot must check the FCOM to verify whether the failure has any impact on the aircraft's approach capability
learning.explanation: The answer provides a good and complete answer to this question: Obviously, failure or malfunctions of any of the systems required to perform an automatic landing can result in a degradation of autoland performance. Additionally, systems which are not directly involved in the autoland sequency can also affect the ability to perform automatic landing and probably result in higher minima. Thus, the pilot must check the FCOM to verify whether the failure has any impact on the aircraft's approach capability. In case the defect causes a reduction in the aircraft's approach capability, a diversion or higher height and/or RVR might be necessary.

content.question: Following an automatic landing, with the ROLL OUT mode engaged, the autopilot…

options.A: applies full reverse thrust to shorten the landing distance.
options.B: controls the rudder and nose wheel steering to keep the aeroplane on the localiser centreline.
options.C: remains engaged until the runway is fully vacated.
options.D: performs an automatic go-around if speed is too high.

key_points: The last two stages of an autoland are: The flare – At 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude
The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare
The roll-out – The autopilot controls the rudder and nose wheel steering to keep the airplane on the localizer centerline
learning.explanation: The last two stages of an autoland are: The flare – At 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare. The roll-out – The autopilot controls the rudder and nose wheel steering to keep the airplane on the localizer centerline. Exceeding a certain distance from the centerline, the autopilot will automatically disconnect, and the pilot flying will need to take over to maintain the centerline using the rudder pedals. Make sure you disconnect the autopilot before making your first turn towards the taxiway. Both of the flight crew members are busy looking for the correct taxiway to exit as the visibility is very poor, so they sometimes forget to disconnect it before vacating the runway.

learning.explanation: In order to free up resources for tasks such as navigation and monitoring of aircraft systems, automatic flight control systems, also known as the autopilot, have been developed to handle the basic tasks of flight control and guidance. An aircraft can be subjected to disturbances about its three control axes i.e. longitudinal (roll), lateral (pitch) and vertical or normal (yaw). Stabilization must therefore be controlled about the same three axes. Control tasks are performed by the inner control loop of the autopilot. It is able to detect and maintain aircraft attitude, which concerns pitch and roll.

learning.explanation: The flight mode annunciator (FMA) is the only indication of the autoflight systems' state of operation. key_points: Note: This should really be in AGK only (there is a version of this question in the AGK section of the bank already)

Please let us know if you see this in the Instrumentation exam, thank you! The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
learning.explanation: Note: This should really be in AGK only (there is a version of this question in the AGK section of the bank already). Please let us know if you see this in the Instrumentation exam, thank you! The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

The aircraft’s flight control computer (FCC) monitors sensors throughout the aircraft to make automatic adjustments in the flight control surface actuators to enhance flight safety and performance, based on the flight control laws. FbW is basically an automated closed-loop control system and its basics elements are: - Reference input provided by either the autopilot or pilot thru the yoke, side stick, pedals or any other actuation element; - The Flight Control Computer (FCC), calculates how much the current aircraft aerodynamic variables deviates from the reference input and defines what action should be commanded to the actuators to maneuver the aircraft according to the flight control laws; - The surface control actuators, which translates the FCC signal command into hydro-mechanical force/torque to change the position/angle of the surface controls (Rudder, Elevators, Slats, Spoilers, Flaps, and Aileron). - Instrumentation or aircraft sensors, which provide the response feedback to the FCC to compare with the reference input and estimate.

content.question:
You are the pilot flying of an aeroplane established on an ILS to perform an Autoland. Your aircraft is equipped with two autopilots, which are both engaged, and the Autoland capability of the aeroplane is fail operational. Passing 400 ft ONE autopilot fails, with the only technical consequence being a downgraded landing capability. Given the information below, what are the consequences of this failure and what should you do?
Approach minima: 0 ft
Alert height: 100 ft

options.A: The aircraft annunciates the failure but you Go Around as there's no time to select a new minima.
options.B: The aircraft does NOT annunciate as the flight is already below the annunciation height.
options.C: The aircraft maintains safe flight conditions and is able to land automatically.
options.D: The aircraft maintains safe flight conditions but is unable to land automatically.

key_points: ALERT HEIGHT The alert height is evaluated and defined during the aircraft certification
It refers only to autoland operations with fail-operational landing system

The alert height defines the point during an approach with the lowest minima (CAT IIIB): - Before which (above AH) a go-around (or full manual take-over) should be decided and initiated if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system (the probability of a second failure remains high and must be considered); - After which (below AH), if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system, the approach and autoland can be continued (the probability of a second failure is negligible)
learning.explanation: ALERT HEIGHT The alert height is evaluated and defined during the aircraft certification. It refers only to autoland operations with fail-operational landing system. The alert height defines the point during an approach with the lowest minima (CAT IIIB): - Before which (above AH) a go-around (or full manual take-over) should be decided and initiated if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system (the probability of a second failure remains high and must be considered); - After which (below AH), if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system, the approach and autoland can be continued (the probability of a second failure is negligible). FAIL-OPERATIONAL AUTOMATIC LANDING SYSTEM An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure below alert height, the remaining part of the automatic system allows the aircraft to complete the approach, flare, and landing. In the event of a failure, the automatic landing system operates as a fail-passive system. FAIL-PASSIVE AUTOMATIC LANDING SYSTEM An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail passive means in case of a failure of any part of the system, the autoland system will turn itself off and the crew has to take over. An example of an autoland sequence: - Approach (APP) mode armed - Localizer and Glide Slope Armed - Localizer Capture - Glide Slope Capture - 400 - 330 feet RA: If FLARE is armed by approximately 350 ft RA, both A/Ps automatically disengage. - At 45 feet Gear Altitude (GA)/ 50 ft RA: The FLARE mode is automatically engaged - Roll-out FAILURES AND ASSOCIATED ACTIONS As a general rule, if a failure occurs above 1000 ft AGL, the approach may be continued if all required actions are completed, the updated approach briefing is performed and the appropriate Decision heigh/altitude set. Below 1000 ft (and down to Alert Height), the occurrence of any failure requires a go around and a reassessment of the landing capability. It has been considered that below 1000 ft, not enough time is available for the crew to perform the necessary switching, to check system configuration and limitation and brief for minima.

content.question: An ADC supplies the autopilot with false speed information. What happens to the precision and stability of this autopilot?

options.B: It is not affected because the FD monitors the AP and gives correct indications to the crew.
options.C: It is not affected because the autopilot will use the speed from the opposite ADC instead.
options.D: It is affected because the AP actuator is directly linked to the ADC speed sensor.

key_points: The Air Data Computer (ADC) collects all relevant air data, automatically eliminates the position errors of its individual sensors, computes the required output parameters and provides them to as many systems as desired
Possible inputs include status pressure (static ports), total pressure (pitot tubes), total air temperature (Rosemount probes) and angle of attack (sensors)
The ADC does not have an output device of its own
learning.explanation: The Air Data Computer (ADC) collects all relevant air data, automatically eliminates the position errors of its individual sensors, computes the required output parameters and provides them to as many systems as desired. Possible inputs include status pressure (static ports), total pressure (pitot tubes), total air temperature (Rosemount probes) and angle of attack (sensors). The ADC does not have an output device of its own. Instead, its computations are displayed on the barometric altimeter, vertical speed indicator, airspeed indicator and Machmeter. In addition, ADC computations are used in the background by many other systems. Automatic flight control systems such as the flight director, the autopilot and the autothrust system receive the same set of data. Any malfunction of an ADC affects all of these instruments/systems.

content.question: A Flight Director (FD) indicates a roll to the right. The pilot manually steers in the direction of the command. During the roll, the FD indication…

options.A: Initially indicates a right roll and adjusts to indicate a left turn of 10° before the required heading is reached.
options.B: adjust the roll command when approaching the required heading.
options.C: disappears as soon as a bank angle of at least 15° is reached.
options.D: keeps indicating a right roll without a change until the required heading is reached.

key_points: In a Flight Director System (FDS), pitch and roll commands compute to achieve or maintain a particular condition of flight
During Heading Mode, the Flight Directors issue commands to guide the aircraft onto the desired heading
Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command
learning.explanation: In a Flight Director System (FDS), pitch and roll commands compute to achieve or maintain a particular condition of flight. During Heading Mode, the Flight Directors issue commands to guide the aircraft onto the desired heading. Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command. When the Pitch Command Bar moves UP, the aircraft pitches upward. When the Roll Command Bar moves RIGHT, the aircraft rolls to the right to align with the commanded direction. Once the initial demand is met, the needle centralizes, it then will indicate a turn to roll out when nearing the required heading.

content.question: A pilot is flying a GNSS non-precision approach using the autopilot. The pilot intends to disconnect the autopilot on final approach after having obtained sufficient visual references to complete a manual landing. When disconnecting the autopilot using the instinctive or quick disengagement control, the pilot should expect…

options.B: A continuous aural and visual master warning highlighting to the pilot that he/she must put the hand on the control column/stick to control the aeroplane.
options.C: At least a single cycle aural and visual master warning to signal that the autopilot is disconnected, and NO ONE is controlling the aeroplane.
options.D: A unique autopilot disconnect aural warning and a visual warning for a limited period of time confirming that the autopilot is disconnected.

key_points: Autopilot disengagement will be announced both visually as flashing lights, and aurally
Furthermore, the lights and tone does not go away until a second confirmation is received from the pilot
For example, pushing the button on the yoke/stick once will disengage the autopilot but trigger the warning
learning.explanation: Autopilot disengagement will be announced both visually as flashing lights, and aurally. Furthermore, the lights and tone does not go away until a second confirmation is received from the pilot. For example, pushing the button on the yoke/stick once will disengage the autopilot but trigger the warning. A second click is needed to silence it. Regardless of how the autopilot is disconnected (automatic or manually), a temporary aural alert will announce autopilot disengagement to the pilots. As we have mentioned above, the aural alert will sound until it's confirmed by the pilot. Therefore, we do not believe that the current correct option is accurate, however it is the only possible answer. CS 25.1329 Automatic pilot system (i) A warning must be provided to each pilot in the event of automatic or manual disengagement of the automatic pilot.
